communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: PRA: Autopsy and coroner’s reports
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the San Francisco Sunshine Ordinance (established in Chapter 67 of the San Francisco Administrative Code) and California Public Records Act (Government Code Section 6250 et seq.) ("CPRA”), and all other applicable laws, please disclose the following records.

Any and all autopsy, death investigation, and coroner’s reports relating to the deaths of the following individuals:

- Name: Herbert Watt, Date of birth: 08-08-1964, Date of death: 01-18-2007

- Name: Brandon Carrillo, Date of birth: 03-11-1990, Date of death: 11-30-2012

- Name: Latima Wright, Date of birth: 04-04-1984, Date of death: 06-05-2014

- Name: George Bradford, Date of birth: 06-04-1964, Date of death: 05-29-2014

- Name: Jonathan Mitchell, Date of birth: 03-20-1965, Date of death: 10-10-2014

- Name: Joseph Lilly, Date of birth: 09-12-1994, Date of death: 12-16-2014

- Name: Matthew Hoffman, Date of birth: 10-10-1982, Date of death: 01-04-2015

- Name: Marvin Day, Date of birth: 01-14-1964, Date of death: 07-02-2015

- Name: Filimoni Raiyawa, Date of birth: 07-27-1958, Date of death: 07-30-2015

- Name: Amilcar Perez-Lopez, Date of birth: 07-25-1994, Date of death: 02-26-2015

- Name: Alice Brown, Date of birth: 04-30-1990, Date of death: 03-17-2015

- Name: Herbert Benitez, Date of birth: 10-30-1987, Date of death: 10-15-2015

- Name: Javier Lopez, Date of birth: 05-31-1990, Date of death: 11-11-2015

- Name: Mario Woods, Date of birth: 07-22-1989, Date of death: 12-02-2015

- Name: Jeremy Andrews, Date of birth: 03-02-1985, Date of death: 01-21-2016

- Name: Luis Gongoria, Date of birth: 04-25-1970, Date of death: 04-07-2016

- Name: Jessica Williams, Date of birth: 01-13-1987, Date of death: 05-19-2016

- Name: Robert Bower, Date of birth: 09-18-1963, Date of death: 06-19-2016

- Name: Abel Margo-Carlos, Date of birth: 06-28-1980, Date of death: 03-24-2017

- Name: Christopher Kliment, Date of birth: 11-15-1987, Date of death: 01-05-2019

- Name: Brandon Wiemann, Date of birth: 06-30-1983, Date of death: 03-17-2020

- Name: Kristopher Le, Date of birth: 10-25-2000, Date of death: 01-17-2021

- Name: Kurt Vonboehrens, Date of birth: 08-09-1986, Date of death: 03-16-2022

- Name: Bradley Titus, Date of birth: 09-11-2005, Date of death: 09-08-2022

If records pursuant to this request are possessed in machine-readable format such as an .xls, .csv spreadsheet file, please provide the record in this format. Please disclose these records in the format in which they are kept, e.g., .ppt, .pptx, .doc, or .docx.

The fundamental rule of the CPRA is a presumption of public access. “In other words, [A]ll public records are subject to disclosure unless the Legislature has expressly provided to the contrary.” Williams v. Superior Court, 5 Cal. 4th 337 (1993). This presumption finds further support in the California Constitution, as amended by Proposition 59 in 2004. “A statute, court rule, or other authority, including those in effect on the effective date of this subdivision, shall be broadly construed if it furthers the people's right of access, and narrowly construed if it limits the right of access.” Cal. Const. Art. 1 § 3(b)(2).

Please provide a determination on this request within 10 days of your receipt of it. If you determine that any or all of the information qualifies for an exemption from disclosure, please note whether, as is normally the case, the exemption is discretionary, and if so whether it is necessary in this case to exercise your discretion to withhold the information. If you determine that some but not all of the information is exempt from disclosure and that you intend to withhold it, please redact it for the time being and make the rest available as requested. In any event, please provide a signed notification citing the legal authorities on which you rely if you determine that any or all of the information is exempt and will not be disclosed.

Please apply a fee waiver to this request. If the request for a fee waiver is denied, please provide notification of any duplication costs exceeding $50 before you duplicate the records. If the request for a fee waiver is denied, please further provide an index of all other requests since 2018 for which a fee waiver was denied, and the reason therefore.

Please respond to this request and disclose the records electronically by email to this MuckRock email address. Please let us know if you have any questions or if we can help ensure this request is the least burdensome possible for your agency while providing a correct and full disclosure in the public interest.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to me via email at dillon@muckrock.com, or by phone at (267) 314-7952. Thank you for your assistance. 

Sincerely,
Dillon Bergin

title: FBI/BOI Records on Galleanisti and Treschiani (1922–1924) – March on Rome / Counter-Revolution Inquiry

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI/BOI Records on Galleanisti and Treschiani (1922–1924) – March on Rome / Counter-Revolution Inquiry
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am requesting access to any FBI or Bureau of Investigation (BOI) files—including reports, field cables, correspondence, or memoranda—concerning Italian-American anarchist groups, specifically the Galleanisti and/or Treschiani, dated between 1922 and 1924.

This request focuses particularly on materials referencing the March on Rome, or containing language about fascism as a “counter-revolution” or “reaction of capital.” I am conducting academic research into early U.S.-based anti-fascist movements and their ideological framing of fascism during this period.

Relevant records may be found under RG 65 or similar FBI/BOI designations. I am open to digital scans. Please let me know if narrowing the date range or search terms would aid in locating responsive records.

Thank you for your time and assistance.

Sincerely,
Dylan Delprato

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dylan D

https://alachuachronicle.com/woman-charged-with-disorderly-conduct-battery-on-an-officer-and-attempted-escape-after-downtown-shooting/

Sincerely,

Jordi

The City of Charleston Police Department will provide a formal acknowledgment within 10 business days informing you of the availability of the non-exempt “public records” that you have requested and providing a time and cost estimate to make those public records available to you. For records more than 24 months old, the City has 20 business days to respond on availability and cost. We do not guarantee that a records search will result in any responsive records being located. 
Fulfillment of FOIA requests is subject to fees for search, retrieval and redaction, as well as fees for providing copies of documents. A deposit of twenty-five (25%) percent of the total reasonably anticipated cost for fulfilling the request may be required prior to searching for or making copies of records. The full amount of the total cost must be paid at the time of the production of the request. 
If the request is granted, the records will be furnished or made available for inspection or copying no later than thirty (30) calendar days from the date on which the formal acknowledgement was provided, unless the records are more than two (2) years old, in which case they will be made available no later than thirty-five (35) calendar days from the date on which the formal acknowledgement was provided. If a deposit is required, the records will be furnished or made available for inspection or copying no later than thirty (30) calendar days from the date on which the deposit is received, unless the records are more than two (2) years old, in which case they will be made available no later than thirty-five (35) calendar days from the date on which the deposit was received to fulfill the request. The Charleston Police Department may impose reasonable rules concerning time and place of access to records. 
* Please note that pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. §30-2-50, obtaining or using public records for commercial solicitation directed to any person in this State is prohibited. A person who knowingly violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars or imprisoned for a term not to exceed one year, or both. 
We do not make public, and will not produce in response to your request, those records that are exempt from disclosure under S.C. Code Ann. § 30-4-40 or other state and federal laws. 
 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the FOIA Records Request Center. You'll receive a formal acknowledgment e-mail from the City within 10 business days (or within 20 business days for records more than 24 months old) when availability and cost have been determined. 
Sincerely, 
Charleston Police Department

--- Please respond above this line --- 

 
 
RE: FOIA REQUEST of August 07, 2025, Reference # L020971-080725 

Dear Jordi Jordi, 

The Charleston Police Department received a FOIA request from you on August 07, 2025 for the following records: 
“To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the South Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

All available body-worn camera footage, dashcam footage, and arrest reports related to the arrest of Preston Scott Postell for disorderly conduct and/or attempted bribery, which reportedly occurred around May 18, 2025, in Charleston, SC, as described in this news article: 
https://abcnews4.com/news/local/charleston-man-arrested-for-disorderly-conduct-attempts-to-bribe-officers-report-wciv-abc-news-4-charleston-sc-south-carolina-college-of-charleston-cofc-sheriff-al-cannon-detention-center 

Please include: 
- All bodycam footage from involved officers 
- Any dashcam footage if applicable 
- Incident reports, booking records, or citations 
- Date, time, and location of the arrest 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Jordi 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fcharleston-police-department-3559%252Fpreston-scott-postell-190833%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAAVaGEmoptJAJcAFqS8iHqRNbA%3A1ukDAF%3ALvndclJNUQRBZA0cOKYV9_mxKocPQPO_Lb2-n6mleE8” 

The Charleston Police Department has reviewed its files and has determined there are no responsive documents to your request. 

This completes the Charleston Police Department response to your FOIA request and this matter is now considered closed. 

You may reply to this email if you have any questions. 

Sincerely, 
Carmen Grimes 

Charleston Police Department

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Roy Walker interaction reports
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Regarding an interaction with Roy Walker on 06/07/2006:
- All incident, dispatch log entries and arrest reports. Incident reports and case records refer to reports produced with notes and narratives, a description of what happened by the responding officer, trace reports, case notes and litigation files
- All unedited body-worn camera / bodycam recordings. I am specifically requesting the unedited body-worn camera recordings captured by all officers present for the full duration of the incident, including audio recordings associated with the footage. If any portion of the requested footage must be redacted, I ask that you clearly indicate the portions that have been redacted and provide an explanation of the legal basis for the redactions
- All 911 or calls for service logs, audio and transcripts
- All computer aided dispatch (CAD) reports and a copy of your department’s dispatch 10 signals/codes, agency dispatch signals/codes and CAD signals/codes

I request these records in their native digital formats and not in formats that degrade the accessibility of the records, such as tabular data converted to PDF or Word files. If converting the native digital format to another high-fidelity format, such as CSV or Excel, please take care not to introduce formatting inconsistencies or errors, which can occur in the conversion process (for example, encoding errors or the inclusion of internal unescaped quotation marks in CSV files). Should the records above represent certain values as numeric codes or abbreviations that are not self-explanatory, I additionally request all records necessary to interpret those codes and abbreviations.

I am a member of the news media. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

Production of Responsive Records on a Rolling Basis: In the event that a portion of the present request is completed before the full request is completed, I ask that the records be produced on a rolling basis.

Request for Explanation of Withholdings and Redactions: If this request is denied in whole or in part, please provide a reasonable description of any withheld materials and a justification for all such withholdings that includes reference to the specific  exemptions authorizing withholding and specific reasons why such exemptions apply. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dillon Bergin

communications.subject: Your City of Santa Ana public records request #25-1903 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
City of Santa Ana ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-1903 has been submitted successfully. This will acknowledge that the City of Santa Ana received your Public Records Act request. The City will respond to your request within ten (10) days of receipt of this request in accordance with the California Public Records Act. Pursuant to the Email and Text Message Retention Policy of the City, all emails and text messages are retained for two (2) years and deleted on a rolling basis thereafter. Please be advised, Public Records Requests are only reviewed during regular business hours, from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Thursday and alternating Fridays.  Visit the online Holiday and Closed Friday Schedule at https://www.santa-ana.org/holiday-and-closed-friday-schedule ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact City of Santa Ana.

Change your email settings | Visit our help center

communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: Untitled
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

An incident that occurred on or around August 2, 2024, at the Applebee’s restaurant in Portage, Indiana:

1. The police incident report and arrest report concerning Shawneesha Cobbs, who was reportedly arrested during a verbal dispute involving an “All You Can Eat” promotion.
2. Any 911 call logs, dispatch logs, or CAD entries related to the incident.
3. Any available body-worn camera footage, dashcam footage, or surveillance footage recorded by the Portage Police Department during the incident.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordi

communications.subject: 24-21624  Shawneesha Cobbs Arrest - Applebee's
communications.communication:
Good morning,
We have received your request for the following:

  *   Police Report/Arrest Report - $4.00
  *   Police CAD/Calls for Service - $2.00
  *   Body Camera Videos - I have forwarded your request to Sgt. Nichols, who handles our Body Camera Videos/Requests.  There is a fee of $150.00 per body camera video.  Sgt. Nichols will advise how many we have.  Payment must be received first, prior to preparing the records for your request.
  *   Our agency does not have Dash Cameras.
 Once we have determined how many body cam videos, we have for this incident, you may mail a check made Payable to the City of Portage for the total copy costs, and address to my attention for prompt processing.  Or you may call me directly (219) 762-3122, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m., Monday - Friday to make a credit card payment by phone.  Should you choose this option to pay, there also is a 3% service fee for using a debit/credit card.


[cid:image001.png@01DC083D.9C651610]
Barbara Vaughan
Portage Police Department
Records
Phone 219-762-3122
Email  bvaughan@portage-in.com
6260 Central Ave, Portage, IN 46368

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE Video Footage
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The public should have access to any unedited audio or visual recordings of ICE's enforcement operations in California between January 6, 2025 to the present. Since at least 2010, ICE has created and made public hundreds of videos of various internal agency operations, including arrests, detention, and removals. Recently ICE and accompanying agencies have released videos of operations in Los Angeles that have included a raid on MacArthur Park. Videographers accompanied the agency, and the content was shared across multiple platforms. Other operations have been videotaped and shared online by the agency.  On one publicly available website, ICE videographers have uploaded videos of agency actions. Given ICE's widespread practice of recording its operations, additional and unedited recordings of ICE operations in California likely exist but have not been made public. These videos contain important information about the tactics used when arresting noncitizens and whether ICE officers are acting in a manner consistent with ICE's own protocols and state and federal due process laws. Because these video and audio records contain information about a critical government function on a matter of significant public interest and concern, FOIA mandates their disclosure.

1. Any audio or visual recordings of ICE operations, including arrests, detention, and removals, in California between January 6, 2025 to the present. 

The Requestor

Joey Scott and Jeremy Lindenfield are both journalists who work in news gathering, including written and visual reporting. Joey Scott is a freelance investigative journalist in Los Angeles. Jeremy Lindenfield is a journalist for Capital and Main news. 

Fee Waiver 

The Requestor seeks a full fee waiver on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is in the public interest and is "likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor." 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). As set forth above, this request aims to further public understanding of ICE programs and practices that directly affect untold numbers of noncitizens as well as members of the public captured in video recordings of ICE enforcement actions. These policies and practices are of interest to the general public. 

The public interest fee waiver provision "is to be liberally construed in favor of waivers for noncommercial requesters." McClellan Ecologic Seepage Situation v. Carlucci, 835 F.2d 1282, 1284 (9th Cir. 1987). The relevant question is whether the requested information is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government, good or bad. See judicial Watch, Inc. v. Rossotti, 326 F.3d 1309, 1314 (D.C. Cir. 2003). Disclosure of the information and report sought is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public's understanding of the treatment of immigrants during enforcement actions. The requested records also relate directly to government operations, including the use and storage of video files that potentially implicate fundamental rights and freedoms, including the right to privacy. The requested records also relate to the relationship between the federal government and private, for-profit contracted entities. 

The records are not sought for commercial use, and the Requestor plans to disseminate the information disclosed through print and other media to the public at no cost. As demonstrated above, the Requestor has both the intent and ability to convey any information obtained through this request to the public and is therefore entitled to a full fee waiver under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). 

Should the request for a full fee waiver be denied, Requestor also seeks a limitation of processing fees pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II) ("fees shall be limited to reasonable standard charges for document duplication when records are not sought for commercial use and the request is made by ... educational or noncommercial scientific institution ... or a representative of the news media") and 6 C.F.R. § 5.11(d)(1) (search fees shall not be charged to "representatives of the news media"). Requestor is a non-profit organization that intends to disseminate the information gathered by this request to the public at no cost, including through the Requestor's website and social media. The Requestor may publish a news story or other publication on the government's treatment of immigrants based on information gathered through this FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE Videos
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear FOIA Officer:

This letter is a request pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5. U.S.C. § 552, by independent journalists working in the capacity of news gathering (the "Requestor"). We seek records about enforcement and removal operations of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an agency of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Specifically, this request seeks records pertaining to the agency's practice of engaging videographers and camera crews to film arrests, raids, and other enforcement actions. This request also seeks records regarding ICE's relationships with private filmmakers and production companies, and the agency's practice of granting private filmmakers access to observe and film agency operations. This request also seeks records regarding ICE's relationships with news outlets, members of the press, and social media influencers to grant them access to observe and film agency operations.  

Since at least 2010, ICE has amassed hundreds of videos of various internal agency operations, including home arrests, workplace raids, and tours of immigration detention facilities. Since Trump took office, the use of videos and filming operations has skyrocketed. 

According to publicly available records, these videos are primarily created by Audiovisual Production Specialists employed by DHS or by freelance videographers hired by ICE and invited to "ride-along" when officers arrest, detain, and remove noncitizens. Further, according to the agency's website, videographers play a critical role in agency operations. During ICE operations, they are not passive observers; they are a "part of the team."4 The raw footage they capture is edited into short films and promotional materials and uploaded for public consumption. On one publicly available website, ICE videographers have uploaded more than 300 videos of agency actions that capture the images of countless noncitizens and
members of the general public. In addition to employing its own videographers and camera crews, ICE regularly contracts with independent filmmakers, documentarians, and multimedia production companies, granting them access to observe and record internal agency operations.8 Under ICE's standard contract agreement, these independent filmmakers and multimedia production companies must provide DHS with a copy of the final, fully edited footage.9 Access to the footage created by these independent filmmakers only expands ICE's film catalog of agency operations.

There is a compelling and urgent need to obtain records and inform the public about ICE's video recording practices, particularly ICE's practice of recording its operations in vulnerable communities. The practice of engaging videographers, journalists, or granting access to independent camera crews and news outlets to document ICE arrests and removal operations implicates the fundamental due process and privacy rights of the subjects of these operations and of countless bystanders captured in the background. These operations also foster a climate of fear and anguish in the communities where these government activities take place. 

The public should have access to information about the circumstances in which ICE permits videographers employed by the government and those who contract with ICE to record arrests, detentions, and removals. The public should also have access to information about how ICE uses, retains, and shares the video footage it has. Because ICE's video recording practices concern a critical government function on a matter of significant public interest and concern, FOIA mandates its disclosure. 

From November 1, 2024 to present
1. All documents, preserved in physical or electronic form, containing a combination of the
following terms:
a. "film(ing)" or "video record(ing)" or "videographer," or "camera crew"; and
b. "field operation(s)" or "fugitive operation(s)" or "arrest" or "raid," or
"enforcement action";
c. "RayBan(s)"
d. "Bill Megulin" 
e. "Fox LA" or "Fox News LA"or "FoxLA"

From November 1, 2024 to the present, in the possession of the following custodians:
a. Any individual who held the title Division Chief, Digital Engagement, Immigration and
Customs Enforcement during the aforementioned time period;
b. Any individual who held the title Chief of Visual Communications, Immigrations and
Customs Enforcement during the aforementioned time period;
c. Any individual who has held the title of Deputy Field Office Director of the Dallas,
El Paso, Los Angeles, or Miami ICE Field Office during the aforementioned
time period;
e. Any individual who has held the title of Assistant Field Office Director of the Dallas,
El Paso, Los Angeles, or Miami ICE Field Office during the aforementioned
time period; or
f. Any Audio and Visual Production Specialist employed by the Department
Homeland Security (DHS) during the aforementioned time period, including
without limitation Todd Packard, Marshall Amey, James Truitt, Corey Bullard,
Blackburn, or Ron Rogers.

2. Any written communication preserved in electronic form, including e-mail correspondence and attached documents, containing a combination of the following terms:
a."video" or "footage" or "B-roll"; and
b. "ride-along" or "field operation(s)" or "fugitive operation(s)" or "arrest" or
"raid";

3. Any complete or signed "DHS Multimedia Agreement," as defined in DHS Instructions 109-01-001, from November 1, 2024 to the present.

4. Written communications preserved in electronic form, including e-mail correspondence
and attached documents, containing the following phrases:
"proposed pilot"; "shooting schedule"; "outline of the production"; or
"approved production"; from November 1, 2025 to the present, in the possession of the following custodians:
b. Brandon A. Montgomery, Director, DHS, Office of Multimedia Liaison; The current Director of DHS' Office of Multimedia Liaison; or Any individual who has held the title of Director of DHS' Office of Multimedia Liaison during the aforementioned time period.

The Requestor seeks a full fee waiver on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is in the public interest and is "likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor." 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). As set forth above, this request aims to further public understanding of ICE programs and practices that directly affect untold numbers of noncitizens as well as members of the public captured in video recordings of ICE enforcement actions. These policies and practices are of interest to the general public. 

The public interest fee waiver provision "is to be liberally construed in favor of waivers for noncommercial requesters." McClellan Ecologic Seepage Situation v. Carlucci, 835 F.2d 1282, 1284 (9th Cir. 1987). The relevant question is whether the requested information is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government, good or bad. See judicial Watch, Inc. v. Rossotti, 326 F.3d 1309, 1314 (D.C. Cir. 2003). Disclosure of the information and report sought is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public's understanding of the treatment of immigrants during enforcement actions. The requested records also relate directly to government operations, including the use and storage of video files that potentially implicate fundamental rights and freedoms, including the right to privacy. The requested records also relate to the relationship between the federal government and private, for-profit contracted entities. 

The records are not sought for commercial use, and the Requestor plans to disseminate the information disclosed through print and other media to the public at no cost. As demonstrated above, the Requestor has both the intent and ability to convey any information obtained through this request to the public and is therefore entitled to a full fee waiver under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). 

Should the request for a full fee waiver be denied, Requestor also seeks a limitation of processing fees pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II) ("fees shall be limited to reasonable standard charges for document duplication when records are not sought for commercial use and the request is made by ... educational or noncommercial scientific institution ... or a representative of the news media") and 6 C.F.R. § 5.11(d)(1) (search fees shall not be charged to "representatives of the news media"). Requestor is a non-profit organization that intends to disseminate the information gathered by this request to the public at no cost, including through the Requestor's website and social media. The Requestor may publish a news story or other publication on the government's treatment of immigrants based on information gathered through this FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: Yakima County Sheriff: February 1988 "Parker" Jane Doe

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Yakima County Sheriff: February 1988 "Parker" Jane Doe
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All Yakima County Sheriff Department documents, dispatch logs, incident reports, follow-up reports, copies of medical examiner's reports or photographs, or anything that could be construed as a "case file" or "case documents" or "relevant documents" related to the discovery of the skeletal remains of an unidentified female decedent who was discovered on February 16th of 1988 near the unincorporated town of Parker. Please include a search for any electronic communication (to or from) either NCIC or WACIC related to these unidentified remains.

This case has been repeatedly covered in the news media, each time with requests to spread information about the case to the public in order to help generate leads which might to assist in identification: https://www.yakimaherald.com/thevanished/yakima-county-coroner-releases-new-portrait-of-woman-found-near-parker-in-1988/article_f2037ee5-02c6-50e9-9b67-7048a0659a4f.html

The Yakima County Sheriff's Office agency case number is: 88-1113.

If the Yakima County Sheriff's Department cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or if certain portions (for example, photographs) must be redacted, please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

As a hobby I research unidentified decedent cases and will attempt to use information released in an attempt to generate leads. Thank you for the Yakima County Sheriff Department's commitment to transparency. I look forward to working with you to resolve this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: Kansas Open Records Request – Floyd Bledsoe Case (1999–2015)

communications.subject: The Kansas Open Records Act Request: Kansas Open Records Request – Floyd Bledsoe Case (1999–2015)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Kansas Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Officer,

 I am requesting access to public records related to the wrongful conviction and eventual exoneration of Floyd Bledsoe, originally convicted in 1999 for the murder of Zetta “Camille” Arfmann in Jefferson County, Kansas, and exonerated in 2015 following new DNA evidence and suppressed confessions by his brother.

 Records Requested:


1. All available interrogation footage of Floyd Bledsoe and his brother, Tom Bledsoe, including original 1999 interviews and any follow-up interrogations or statements from 2007–2015.


2. Original handwritten or typed confessions by Tom Bledsoe, including the one found posthumously.


3. Forensic case files related to DNA testing conducted during the original investigation and post-conviction analysis (2015).


4. Internal memos, police reports, or KBI summaries regarding the handling of evidence in the Bledsoe case.


5. Any Brady materials or prosecutorial correspondence concerning evidence withheld from the defense team during trial.


6. Case review or internal audit files compiled after Floyd Bledsoe’s exoneration.


7. Any civil complaint filings, settlements, or investigative memos tied to misconduct or policy violations associated with this case.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: Request for Public Records Relating to Richard Eugene Glossip 1997

communications.subject: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Request for Public Records Relating to Richard Eugene Glossip 1997
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oklahoma Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

I am respectfully requesting access to and copies of all public records relating to Richard Eugene Glossip (ODOC Inmate #112493), who was convicted in connection with the 1997 murder of Barry Van Treese and has remained on Oklahoma’s death row since.

This request specifically seeks materials relevant to:

Requested Records

1. All available interrogation or interview footage (video or audio) involving:

Justin Sneed (the confessed killer)

Richard Glossip

Any other persons of interest in the original 1997 investigation or post-conviction inquiries.


2. Handwritten or signed confessions from Justin Sneed, including all versions and recantations.


3. Internal correspondence (emails, memos, reports) from 1997–2023 between:

Prosecutors, investigators, and/or ODOC staff discussing Glossip’s guilt, execution stays, or exoneration efforts.



4. Forensic evidence reports and lab results (e.g., fingerprints, DNA) used or reviewed in the original trial and post-conviction proceedings.


5. Documents referenced in the Oklahoma Attorney General’s 2023 investigative report, especially regarding:

Brady violations

Witness coercion

Suppression or destruction of evidence



6. Execution records or logs for Glossip (including dates of scheduled executions, stays, final meal orders, medical exams, psychological evaluations, or execution preparation memos).


7. Inmate correspondence to/from Richard Glossip, if publicly releasable under Oklahoma law (e.g., legal communications with AG, clemency board, etc.).


8. Courtroom audio, video, or transcripts of post-2015 hearings related to his innocence claims, pending SCOTUS appeal, or investigative report discussions.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Officer,

 I respectfully request access to public records relating to the February 2014 beating and misidentification of Mr. James King by undercover law enforcement officers operating as part of a joint task force with the FBI.

Requested Records (Grand Rapids Police Department)

1. Surveillance or bodycam footage capturing the stop, seizure, beating, or arrest of Mr. King.


2. Incident and arrest reports, medical intake records, and use-of-force documentation tied to the case.


3. Any internal communications or interagency emails regarding King’s identity and the decision to arrest him.


4. Reports, memos, or investigations from OPD supervisors or internal affairs concerning this incident.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: Public Records Request – Arrest & Internal Communications Related to Anthony Novak Parody Facebook Case (2022–2023).

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Public Records Request – Arrest & Internal Communications Related to Anthony Novak Parody Facebook Case (2022–2023).
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Access Officer,

 I respectfully request access to public records concerning the case commonly known as Novak v. Parma Police Department, involving the creation of a parody Facebook page impersonating the police department. Specifically, I seek records from 2022–2023 that address the following:

Requested Materials

1. Body camera footage and in-car video from the arrest of Anthony Novak, specifically documenting any interaction related to the parody page.


2. Booking and intake video from the Parma jail for Novak’s arrest.


3. Incident reports, complaint summaries, or arrest logs connected to the parody page and arrest.


4. Officer emails or internal communications, including but not limited to discussions on:

Creation or discovery of the parody page

Legal response or strategy for handling Novak’s case

Perceived policy violations or free speech concerns



5. Any use-of-force reports or internal investigations triggered by Novak’s arrest.


Context for Clarity

Individual involved: Anthony Novak

Nature of incident: Arrest for a parody social media page mimicking Parma Police, charged with “disrupting public services.”

Relevant legal issues:

First Amendment rights vs. qualified immunity

Satire and parody as protected speech

Wrongful arrest under false impression of impersonation

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: Communications Regarding SCREEN/KOSA Acts and Foreign NGO Influence

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Communications Regarding SCREEN/KOSA Acts and Foreign NGO Influence
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

from January 1, 2022, to present concerning:

1.The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) and/or the SCREEN Act, including internal drafts, reviews, or recommendations.

2.Communications, emails, meeting logs, or policy submissions involving:
- a) National Center on Sexual Exploitation (NCOSE)
- b) Collective Shout
- c) CEASE (Centre to End All Sexual Exploitation)
- d) Carnegie UK Trust
- e) Yoti (digital ID software provider)

3.Discussions regarding age verification systems, child internet safety standards, or external digital identity technologies.

This request is submitted with reference to the July 25, 2025 Interim Staff Report of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee titled:
“The Foreign Censorship Threat: How the European Union’s Digital Services Act Compels Global Censorship and Infringes on American Free Speech.”

This report documents concerns that foreign laws are being used to impose domestic censorship goals through indirect means. This FOIA request seeks to determine whether similar tactics were employed by the aforementioned NGOs or agencies.

I request a waiver of fees as this is a matter of significant public interest. I am submitting this on behalf of Alathea LLC.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Demosthenes Alathea

title: Public Records Request – Sandra Hemme Investigation, Interrogation, and Related Files

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Public Records Request – Sandra Hemme Investigation, Interrogation, and Related Files
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

 I hereby request access to all public records related to the investigation, prosecution, and reversal of the conviction of Sandra Hemme in the 1980 murder of Patricia Jeschke—including previously undisclosed or newly surfaced documents.

Specifically, I seek:

1. All audio and video recordings of interrogations of Sandra Hemme from November–December 1980—including interviews conducted at hospitals or crime scenes.


2. Transcripts or handwritten notes of each interrogation session.


3. Detective and investigative reports, including observations on Hemme’s mental and physical condition during questioning and references to the now-deceased officer Michael Holman.


4. Internal memos, emails, or reports regarding the handling, storage, or withholding of evidence


5. Chain-of-custody logs for key physical evidence and any documents submitted during the 2024 evidentiary hearing.


6. Policy or correspondence related to exculpatory evidence—especially involving visits to the crime scene, psychological vulnerability, and coercive interrogation tactics.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P061105-080625
communications.communication:
Dear Brown Pearl: 
Our office received your open records request pursuant to Missouri's Sunshine Law, Chapter 610, RSMo. Your request has been assigned number P061105-080625. The Patrol is committed to adhering to the Sunshine Law and to ensuring that the public obtains access to open records that are not otherwise closed by law. The Sunshine Law requires each public agency to adhere to certain standards. This letter is designed to ensure that you understand our process for fulfilling your records request. Three Business Day Notice Requirement: 
The requested records are not immediately available for dissemination or inspection. The Patrol is required to notify you that additional research time will be required to fulfill the request. This correspondence satisfies the Sunshine Law's notice requirement within the required three business day period. Section 610.023.3, RSMo. 
 Additional Research Time is Required: 
The Patrol receives thousands of open records requests each month. Our Patrol Records Division personnel are dedicated to meeting the intent of Missouri's Sunshine Law and strive to respond to each request in a timely manner. The Patrol operates in all 114 Missouri counties and the independent city of St. Louis. Accordingly, many records maintained by the agency are not centrally located within, or immediately accessible to, the Patrol's Custodian of Records in Jefferson City. Our staff must research your request and ensure that we have captured all responsive records  ̶  regardless of their location within the agency. The research process is time-consuming, but we will make every effort to expedite your request. Estimated Time for Completion: 
The majority of our requests are fulfilled within thirty business days. Some requests require additional research time due to their scope or complexity. Our team will conduct an initial review of your request. If we estimate that the request will be fulfilled within thirty business days, we will not send an updated time estimate. However, if we estimate that the request will take longer than thirty business days, we will provide an updated time estimate that provides a detailed justification for the additional research time. Billing: 
As it relates to billing, Missouri law allows the Patrol to charge fees for copies and research time. Specifically, "[r]esearch time required for fulfilling records requests may be charged at the actual cost of research time." Section 610.026, RSMo. The Missouri Supreme Court recently determined that "staff time is the time required to provide access to public records maintained on computer facilities, recording tapes or disks, videotapes or films, pictures, maps, slides, graphics, illustrations or similar audio or visual items". Gross v. Parson, 624 S.W.3d 877, 884-89 (Mo. 2021) (internal quotations omitted). 
The Patrol will never bill you for redaction time or any research time conducted by our legal staff. You will only be charged for copies and staff research time as permitted by Missouri law. Please let us know if you have questions related to the billing estimate. 
Our team will forward a bill estimate to your attention once we have calculated the permissible costs and fees. The Patrol will not provide the responsive records until receipt of payment. Section 610.026.2, RSMo. 
We appreciate your patience as we review, research, and fulfill your open records request. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. If you wish to withdraw or clarify your request, or if you have questions, please call our office at (573) 526-6146, or (573) 526-6167. 
 
Sincerely, 
Gerard G. Callahan 
Custodian of Records 
 
Login Link: https://mshp.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/Login.aspx

title: FOIL Request – Arrest of Jodi Haddad (June 2024, Victory Chrysler, Rome, NY)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request – Arrest of Jodi Haddad (June 2024, Victory Chrysler, Rome, NY)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law §84 et seq.), I request unredacted digital copies of all video footage related to the arrest of Jodi Haddad, age 48, of Stockbridge, NY, who was arrested in June 2024 for allegedly stealing over $50,000 from Victory Chrysler in Rome, NY.

According to public reports, Haddad was charged with grand larceny and falsifying business records following a two-month investigation by the Oneida County Sheriff's Office. She was arraigned and released pending a future court date in Rome City Court.

Please include all body-worn camera, dashcam, interior patrol car, and interview room footage related to her arrest, transport, and processing.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Daniele Mazzei

title: Open Records Request – FOIA: Leonard Cure Traffic Stop & Interrogation Materials (Oct 16, 2023)

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Open Records Request – FOIA: Leonard Cure Traffic Stop & Interrogation Materials (Oct 16, 2023)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

I respectfully request the following materials related to the death of Leonard Cure, who was fatally shot during a traffic stop on October 16, 2023, in Camden County:

A. Video and Audio Recordings

1. Full video recordings (body-worn and dash-camera) capturing the entire traffic stop and shooting event.


2. Any audio or video footage of subsequent interrogation, either at the scene or at any station or holding facility, including questioning of Mr. Cure before his death.



B. Written Reports and Internal Communications

3. Incident and use-of-force reports, internal summaries, and memos related to the traffic stop.


4. Chain-of-custody logs or documentation for all video/audio recordings.


5. Policies or logs regarding evidence release and record handling within the Sheriff’s Office concerning this incident.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: Public Records Request – Interrogation Footage and Confession Records of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown (1983 Case, Robeson County)

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request – Interrogation Footage and Confession Records of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown (1983 Case, Robeson County)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Officer,

 I am requesting access to public records pertaining to the interrogation, confession, arrest, and conviction of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown, in relation to the 1983 murder of Sabrina Buie in Red Springs, Robeson County.

Specifically, I request:

1. Any audio or video recordings of the interrogations of Henry McCollum and/or Leon Brown conducted in or around September 1983.


2. Transcripts or written statements/confessions extracted during these interrogations.


3. Detective notes or internal reports summarizing the interrogation process or referencing the confessions.


4. Chain of custody or custody logs indicating where interrogation-related materials have been stored or maintained.


5. Any additional materials that were entered as evidence in court or reviewed during post-conviction proceedings, especially in relation to:

Motions to suppress

Allegations of coercion

Cognitive disability evaluations of the defendants

The confessions obtained during these interrogations were later called into question and invalidated after DNA evidence exonerated both men in 2014, identifying another individual as the true perpetrator.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: FOIA Request – Interrogation Footage & Related Records: Jessie Misskelley Jr. – West Memphis Three Case

communications.subject: Arkansas Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request – Interrogation Footage & Related Records: Jessie Misskelley Jr. – West Memphis Three Case
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arkansas Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Custodian of Records,

I respectfully request access to and copies of public records related to the interrogation of Jessie Misskelley Jr., which took place on or about June 3, 1993, in connection with the investigation of the West Memphis Three case (State of Arkansas v. Jessie Misskelley Jr., CR-93-450).

I am specifically requesting:

1. Any and all audio and/or video recordings of the police interrogation of Jessie Misskelley Jr., including full unedited sessions.


2. Transcripts, typed or handwritten, of the interrogation proceedings.


3. Officer reports or notes, including any documentation detailing the duration, location, or methods used in the interrogation.


4. Any records indicating video editing, omissions, or redactions, including chain of custody reports.


5. If available, records referenced in court proceedings, including exhibits submitted in CR-93-450, that pertain to the interrogation footage or its content.



This interrogation was central to the prosecution’s case and has been referenced in numerous court filings, appeals, and legal reviews, including:

Misskelley’s Motion to Suppress Confession (1993),

Arkansas Supreme Court opinion in Misskelley v. State, 915 S.W.2d 702 (Ark. 1996),

and subsequent reviews by legal scholars and innocence projects.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sonny Albarado, a citizen of Arkansas, in coordination with Brown Pearl.

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Decertification List
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

DCJS's Master Decertification List,  including  but not limited to all pending, final, prior and reinstated police decertification data. 

Data dictionary and documentation 
I also request all documentation that describes the layout of the database’s tables and fields, and that provides the definitions of any field names, codes, and abbreviations used in the database. This information may be gathered together in a single document like a data dictionary, entity layout, or user's guide. If that is the case, I request access to and copy of said document. Should the records above represent certain values as numeric codes or abbreviations that are not self-explanatory, I additionally request all records necessary to interpret those codes and abbreviations.

Data format 
I request these records in their native digital formats and not in formats that degrade the accessibility of the records, such as tabular data converted to PDF or Word files. If converting the native digital format to another high-fidelity format, such as CSV or Excel, please take care not to introduce formatting inconsistencies or errors, which can occur in the conversion process (for example, encoding errors or the inclusion of internal unescaped quotation marks in CSV files).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Dillon Bergin.

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

In a February 2025 appearance on Fox News, Attorney General Pam Bondi was asked the following by a Fox News journalist: “The DOJ may be releasing the list of Jeffrey Epstein’s clients. Will that really happen?” Bondi responded: “It is sitting on my desk right now to review. That has been a directive by President Trump. I am reviewing that.”  You can see the full interview here: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/bondi-says-epstein-client-list-sitting-my-desk-right-now-reviewing-jfk-mlk-files

I seek all of the Epstein-related records that Bondi was referring to during this interview appearance, including the document or documents she was referring to when she stated "It is sitting on my desk right now to review." This request also seeks the "list of Jeffrey Epstein's clients" that Bondi was asked about by the Fox News reporter and confirmed having in her possession during the interview appearance.

I do not seek a copy of the publicly available list of Epstein's associates that was unsealed by a judge in 2024 in a civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell, and which is described in this CBS News article: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/jeffrey-epstein-list-associates-unsealed-judge-rules/

I am a reporter for The Nation magazine and other outlets. I seek a fee waiver, but if that waiver is denied I am willing to pay up to $25 for these records.

I seek expedited processing for this request. The information I seek could shed light on a matter of urgent and compelling public interest -- namely, the potential involvement of federal government personnel in the alleged sex trafficking operation organized by the late Jeffrey Epstein. This information is at the center of public discourse at this moment, and the Epstein case is a matter that involves the White House, Congress and numerous judicial bodies. It is imperative that the public obtain information on this matter in a timely matter, particularly given the corrosive effects the Epstein case has had on trust in government. For the reasons above, I ask that my request be given expedited processing because there is an urgency to inform the public about actual or alleged federal government activity, and I am a person primarily engaged in disseminating information. I intend to use the requested records to inform the public about actual government activity. I certify the foregoing to be true and correct to the best of my knowledge and belief.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias
